newsitem.title: UK: Small car sectors seen showing fastest growth.
newsitem.headline: Small car sectors seen showing fastest growth.

text.p: The small car sector is set to show a boom in production over the next five years, with world-wide output seen surging by 36 percent between 1996 and 2002, according to the latest Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) survey.
Vehicles like the Rover Mini and Ford Motor Co's Ka are set to fuel explosive growth in capacity in the so-called A and sub-B segments.

The forecast of a 36 percent hike in smaller car production compares with overall passenger car output growing by just over 12 percent between 1996 and 2002, fuelled by emerging and developing market demand.
The sports utility vehicle (SUV) market growth is seen second only to the small car segment, with SUVs forecast to notch up 19 percent growth by 2002.

Multi-purpose vehicles (MPV) are expected to push ahead in developed markets but this "will be offset by low penetration in fast-growing developing markets" said the EIU's "World Production Forecasts" survey.

Segment B cars, vehicles which include the Vauxhall Astra and Ford Escort models, are seen growing production by 13.9 percent over the period. "Although this segment will benefit from a shift towards smaller cars, particularly in Europe and Japan, its potential will be reduced by the expansion of the sub-B segments," said the EIU.
The Escort-sized C segment of vehicles and the MPVs are seen delivering growth of 12 percent each, with the C category continuing to dominate world sales.

The next vehicle-size up, the D segment, is seen achieving below-average growth of six percent and the luxury and executive car segments E and F will be even lower, seeing production grow by just five percent through to 2002.
